Graphical abstract The isoprene polymerization kinetics by using TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts (TMC) with different titanium contents were studied for better understanding the possible active-specie structures of heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta (Z-N) catalysts for conjugated diene polymerizations. The catalytic features including the catalytic activity (CA), number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]), rate constant for polymerization (kp), stereoregularity of these TMC catalysts were studied. The low titanium content catalyst TMC-1 (Ti = 0.09 wt.%) with more isolated mononuclear titanium species showed higher CA and yielded cis-1,4-/trans-1,4- mixed microstructure polyisoprene with low molecular weight (M w) in the initial polymerization stage. The medium high titanium content catalyst TMC-2 (Ti = 2.38 wt.%) with more clustered mononuclear titanium species showed lower CA and yielded cis-1,4-/trans-1,4- mixed microstructure polyisoprene with high M w in the early stage of polymerization. The high titanium content catalyst TMC-3 (Ti = 3.76 wt.%) presented lowest CA and yielded high trans-1,4- polyisoprene with higher M w. Keywords Heterogeneous Z-N catalyst Titanium content Trans-1,4-polyisoprene Active species Catalytic mechanism 1 Introduction The heterogeneous Z-N catalysts have been the most essential industrial catalysts for α-olefin polymerizations since discovered in 1953. Theoretical and experimental studies on the catalytic mechanism [1–19] and active center structures [20–35] of the heterogeneous Z-N catalysts for α-olefin polymerization have been reported. However, the heterogeneous feature combining with trace content and easy deactivation of the active centers, complex reactions among the components of the Z-N catalysts bring formidable barriers for better understanding of the active-specie structures and catalytic mechanism of the heterogeneous Z-N catalysts [36–38], especially for conjugated diene polymerization [39–42]. In order to distinguish the structure and catalytic behavior of various active centers, TiCl3/MgCl2 [43–49] and TiCl4/MgCl2 [50–56] model catalysts with different titanium contents were used for ethylene and propylene polymerizations. The low titanium content TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts (Ti ≤ 0.1 wt.%) composed by isolated mononuclear TiCl4 reacted with alkylaluminum to produce 30–70 % of isolated Ti3+ species [50,51], which showed higher catalytic efficiency and mainly produced low stereospecific polypropylene with low M w [44,45]. However, when electron donor was introduced into the polymerization system, the low stereoregular active centers could transform into high stereoregular ones [56]. Fan et al. [37,38] found that the catalyst with low titanium content showed a larger specific surface area and porosity, a higher polymerization activity which was mainly due to the higher [C*]/[Ti], and produced polyethylene with low M w. With the titanium content of the catalyst increasing from 0.07 wt.% to 5 wt.%, the ethylene polymerization activity first increased and then decreased rapidly, and the M w of the obtained polymers gradually increased and the molecular weight distribution (M w/M n, MWD) became broad [54]. Ti species in high titanium content catalyst (Ti ≥ 1.2 wt.%) mainly existed in cluster form [50]. The clustered titanium species in high titanium content catalysts showed reduced propylene polymerization activity and yielded high isotactic polypropylene with high M w [45]. Although the high titanium content catalyst produced fewer active centers in the initial stage, a much larger increase for [C*]/[Ti] in the high titanium content catalyst (Ti =1.0 wt.%) system was observed than that in the low titanium content catalyst system [37]. H2 was a significantly effective chain transfer agent for the isotactic active species of catalyst. However, H2 had little effect on the atactic active species in the low titanium content catalyst [46]. Many researchers [15,43,57–59] agreed that isolated mononuclear TiCl4 on MgCl2 (110) was the most stable species (Fig. 1 a), while the binuclear Ti2Cl8 on MgCl2 (104) was unstable structures (Fig. 1b) [34]. Our previous work [60–66] found that TiCl4/MgCl2 type Z-N catalysts were efficient for high trans-1,4- polymerizations of isoprene (Ip) and butadiene (Bd). A mechanism model for the stereoselectivity polymerization of Bd and Ip with the TMC was proposed [40–42]. The reactions of the alkylaluminum with the precatalysts (TiCl4/MgCl2) firstly formed low sterically hindered active species (C*-2) which showed low trans-1,4- stereoselectivity. With the absorbing of AlR2Cl on the adjacent Mg atoms around the C*-2, C*-2 were gradually converted into highly sterically hindered active species (C*-1) which showed high trans-1,4- stereoselectivity, and C*-1 eventually became the dominated active species in the polymerization. However, the exact structures of the active species for the trans-1,4 specific polymerization of Bd and Ip are still unclear. In this article, TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts with different titanium content were used for the isoprene polymerizations. The catalytic activity (CA), [C*]/[Ti], microstructure and M w of the polyisoprenes and its evolution with polymerization time were investigated in detail. The specific structure and its catalytic behavior of the active species in the catalysts with different titanium content were correlated firstly for better understanding the catalytic mechanism of the heterogeneous catalyst for conjugated diene polymerizations. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The TiCl4/MgCl2 catalysts (TMC-1 (Ti = 0.09 wt.%), TMC-2 (Ti = 2.38 wt.%), TMC-3 (Ti = 3.76 wt.%)) with different titanium contents were prepared in our laboratory. Isoprene (polymerization grade, supplied by the Shandong Huaju Polymer materials Ltd. Co.) was purified by distillation under reduced pressure and dried with molecular sieve before use. Triisobutyl aluminum (TIBA, purity > 98 %) was supplied by the Yanshan Petrochemical Co., China). 2-thiophenecarbonyl chloride (TPCC, aladdin, purity > 99 %) was diluted with toluene before use. Toluene and n-heptane was purified by distillation with metallic sodium before use. 2.2 Activated TMC catalysts Activated TMC catalysts for the XPS measurements were prepared in a N2 atmosphere. 1 g TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst which was dispersed in 50 mL refined n-heptane was reacted with TIBA under Al/Ti = 50 (mol/mol) at 30 °C in a 100 mL dried flask and remained stirring for 3 min. Then after another 2 min standing, the supernatant was removed and 30 mL n-heptane was added into the flask with keeping stirring for 10 s, and then the supernatant was taken out. The above washing process was repeated thrice. Finally, the activated TMC catalyst was isolated and dried thoroughly under inert atmosphere. 2.3 Polymerization Polymerization of isoprene was conducted in a 100 mL or 250 mL flask with stirring under constant temperature and nitrogen atmosphere [40]. The purged and vacuumed flask was filled with isoprene-toluene mixture with isoprene concentration of 50 wt.%. After a precise amount of TIBA was injected into the flask, the calculated amount of solid TMC was added to start the polymerization at 30 °C. The polymerization was quenched by a toluene solution of TPCC with TPCC/Al = 3 (mol/mol), and stirred for 5 min at 50 °C [67,68]. Then, excess acidic ethanol containing 1 wt.% BHT (2,6-Di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol) was added to the polymerization system to end the reaction. The precipitated polyisoprene was collected and washed thrice using ethanol, and the polyisoprene was dried in a vacuum oven at 45 °C to constant weight at last. 2.4 Characterization The titanium contents in the catalysts were determined via UV spectrophotometer (Spectrumlab 725 s) by measuring the absorbance of sulfuric acid solution of TMC at 410 nm according to reference [69]. Raman spectra of the TMC were recorded with Invia spectrometer using a 532 nm white laser. The catalyst samples were sealed in two slides under nitrogen atmosphere in glove box. The FT-IR spectra of the TMC were recorded by Bruker (TENSOR II) infrared spectrometer. 32 scans were used during the test with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The catalysts were mixed with liquid paraffin before test to protect active species. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were carried out by ESCA Lab 250Xi multifunction photoelectron spectroscopy analyzer with a monochromatic Al Kα source operating at 200 W (Thermo Scientific Co.). The basic vacuum in the analysis chamber was 3 × 10−9 mbar during analysis. Binding energy was calibrated using the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. The M w and M w/M n (MWD) were characterized by means of gel permeation chromatography (GPC) (HLC-8320GPC). The analysis was performed at 40 °C using THF as solvent, and polystyrene standards for calibration was adopted. The microstructure of polyisoprene was characterized by 1H-NMR spectra using Bruker 500 MHz spectrometer at 25 °C using CDCl3 (containing tetramethylsilane as standard) as solvent. 2.5 Determination of the number of active centers 1) Polymer purification [67,68]: the above TPCC-quenched polymers were purified thrice by dissolution–precipitation step. Then the dried polymers were extracted with ethanol for 12 h. Finally, the polymer was dried under vacuum at 45 °C. 2) Sulfur content ([S]) determination: the purified polymer was weighed, and the [S] of the polyisoprene was detected by a YHTS-2000 ultraviolet fluorescent sulfur analyzer (Taizhou Yinhe Instrument Co., Ltd.). Each sample was measured at least three times, and the average value was finally obtained. 3) The [C*]/[Ti] of polymerization was obtained according to the measured [S] ([C*]=[S]) [67]. 4) Estimation of the rate constant for chain propagation (kp): Since the polymerization conversion was less than 5 wt.%, it was assumed that the isoprene concentration in the polymerization system change little. And kp was obtained from the following equation. k p ≈ R p × [ C * ] − 1 × [ I p ] − 1 where Rp was the instantaneous polymerization rate of isoprene, [C*] was the instantaneous concentration of the active center in the polymerization system and [Ip] was the equilibrium isoprene concentration in toluene at 30 °C. 2.6 DFT simulation A density functional theory (DFT) was used to calculate and simulate the infrared and Raman spectra of two titanium precatalysts with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface [34,57,70–72] (Fig. 2 ). A semiflexible (MgCl2)11 cluster was used to support the isolated mononuclear Ti species. A semiflexible (MgCl2)16 cluster was used to support the clustered mononuclear Ti species. The results of all DFT calculations were obtained by using the Gaussian 09 program. The B3LYP-D3 [73,74] functional was used for geometry optimization and subsequent frequency calculation. The 6−31G* basis set was used for Mg and Cl, and the Stuttgart Dresden triple zata effective core potential basis set SDD was used for Ti. The calculated frequency was corrected by the frequency correction factor (0.9614) to obtain the spectrum [75]. During the geometry optimization, the atoms at the edge of the model were frozen while the remaining parts of MgCl2 units were relaxed. This hybrid approach allowed some relaxation of atoms at the surface, while keeping the overall MgCl2 crystal geometry. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts Based on the simulation from Busico and Zerbi [34,57], the binding of mononuclear TiCl4 on MgCl2 (110) was deemed as the most strongest one and mononuclear Ti species might be the precatalyst for olefin polymerization. In this work, the isolated mononuclear TiCl4 species and clustered mononuclear TiCl4 species with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface were adopted as model precatalysts for the DFT simulation. As shown in the Raman spectra simulated by DFT (Fig. 3 A), the isolated mononuclear titanium on MgCl2 (110) showed the characteristic Raman scattering lines at 280 cm−1 and 430 cm−1, and the clustered mononuclear titanium on MgCl2 (110) showed the characteristic Raman scattering lines at 277 cm−1 and 434 cm−1. The measured Raman signals of the TMC-2 and TMC-3 precatalysts (Fig. 3a) were in good agreement with the predictions and showed obvious scattering lines at about 280 cm−1 and 438 cm−1, indicating the existences of clustered mononuclear titanium as predominant structures and minor isolated mononuclear titanium in TMC-2 and TMC-3. The TMC-1 with rather low titanium content was hard to observe the scattering lines or absorbance peaks of titanium due to the detection limitation of the instruments. In addition, the Raman scattering lines appearing at 376 cm−1 in the experimental Raman spectra were ascribed to free or physisorbed mononuclear TiCl4 with tetrahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface, which were unstable and could be removed easily by washing with hexane [57]. Raman lines at 230 and 145 cm−1 were attributed to the crystalline MgCl2 [57,76,77]. The FT-IR spectra simulated by DFT (Fig. 3B) predicated the clustered mononuclear titanium showing characteristic absorption peak at 430−450 cm−1, which was observed in Fig. 3b at 445 cm−1. The intensity of peak at 445 cm−1 increased with the increase in titanium content of TMC catalyst. Combining the above results from experimental measurements and DFT simulation, it can be concluded that there are at least three kinds of titanium species including clustered mononuclear titanium (majority structure), isolated mononuclear titanium with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface and physisorbed mononuclear TiCl4 with tetrahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface in the catalysts. The content of the three titanium species increased with the increase in supported titanium in the TMC catalysts. In order to analyze the detail structures of the active centers, the TMC precatalysts were activated by TIBA with the same Al/Ti molar ratio as in isoprene polymerization. Heptane was used instead of isoprene monomer to prevent guard effects from the propagation chains. The XPS spectra of the TMC catalysts and TIBA activated TMC catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . Compared with the nascent TMC-2 catalyst, the binding energy (BE) and full width at half maximum intensity (FWHM) of the TIBA activated TMC catalyst shifted to the lower and smaller values, indicating the change in oxidation state of titanium (Fig. 4b) [78]. For nascent catalyst TMC-2, peak at Ti 2p3/2 with BE at 459.5 eV representing the formation of titanium/magnesium complex (TiMgxCly) was mainly composed of Ti (IV) species [79–81]. While TIBA activated TMC-2 catalyst, Ti (IV) species were partly reduced to Ti (III) and Ti (II) species which was proved by fitting split the peaks at Ti 2p3/2, as shown in Fig. 4d. The summary of the XPS spectra was shown in Table 1 . Based on the fitting split peak at Ti 2p3/2, the content of the Ti (III) and Ti(II) species in TIBA activated TMC-2 was 31.4 % and 9.9 %, respectively. Therefore, it was deduced that the Ti3+ as the majority species contributed to the catalytic polymerization of isoprene. More than half of the Ti (IV) species were not reduced. In addition, Al elements were observed in the TIBA activated TMC catalysts, which were absent in the nascent TMC catalysts. These indicated that the aluminium compounds are adsorbed stably on the catalyst surface during the TMC activation process with TIBA, which provided a direct support for the aluminium compound absorption on the solid catalyst surface in our proposed catalytic model of the heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta catalyst for diene polymerization [82–84]. 3.2 Isoprene polymerization 3.2.1 Polymerization kinetics and catalytic behaviors Isoprene polymerization kinetics were carried out by TiCl4/MgCl2 (TMC)-TIBA catalysts at 30 °C. The data of polymerization was summarized in Table 2 . TMC with different titanium content showed different catalytic properties at different polymerization stage (Table 2 and Fig. 5 (a,b)). In the initial stage of polymerization (conversion≤ 1 wt.%), the low titanium content catalyst (TMC-1) showed a higher catalytic activity (CA) and conversion. As the polymerization time continued to prolong, the CA decreased greatly. The TMC-2 and TMC-3 catalysts with relatively high titanium content presented relatively lower CA in the initial stage of polymerization compared to that of TMC-1 catalyst. However, when polymerization time exceeded 30 min, TMC-2 catalyst showed a rapid increase in conversion, while TMC-3 presented rather low CA during the whole polymerization process. The low-titanium content catalyst (TMC-1) did yield more active centers in the first 10 min, which showed higher kp (Fig. 5d). The [C*]/[Ti] from TMC-1 grew faster in the initial 15 min (Fig. 5c) and reached as high as 50 mol% with the proceeding of polymerization, indicating the easy contacting and rapid reaction between TiCl4 and TIBA to form active centers. While the medium high titanium content catalyst (TMC-2) yielded less [C*]/[Ti] throughout the polymerization process and the [C*]/[Ti] increased slowly with the polymerization time, which was consistent with the change of polymerization rate. The TMC-3 catalyst with 3.76 wt.% titanium activated by TIBA yielded very low active centers. It can be deduced that the large amount of isolated mononuclear titanium species in the low titanium content catalyst reacted easily with the TIBA and rapidly converted into active center, which showed relatively high kp and higher CA in the early stages of polymerization. However, all the TMC catalysts activated by TIBA showed a decay kp value as the polymerization proceeds. While the kp of TMC-1 species decayed greatly with the increase in the polymerization time. 3.2.2 Polymer microstructure The microstructure evolution of the polyisoprene (trans-1,4 and cis-1,4) under varied polymerization time were shown in Table 2 and Fig. 6 (The 1H-NMR spectra of polyisoprene as shown in Fig. S1 in Supplementary data). Polyisoprenes from TMC catalysts showed 85–95 % trans-1,4 units and 5–10 % cis-1,4 units in the early stages of polymerization. But the content of cis-1,4 units decreased gradually over time, and finally, high trans-1,4 polyisoprene was obtained (Fig. 6a). This microstructure evolution was attributed to the transformation of active species from low stereoregular ones to high stereoregular ones with varied polymerization time by using heterogeneous Z-N catalyst [39–42]. The catalysts with different titanium do have different catalytic features. As Fig. 6b indicated, the TMC-1 catalyst with low titanium content yielded polymers with relatively low trans-1,4 units, while TMC-3 always yielded polymers with relatively high trans-1,4 units during the polymerization process. The experimental phenomenon reflected that the exact structures of titanium species might different in the TMC catalysts with different titanium content. It was assumed that the isolated mononuclear TiCl4 and clustered mononuclear TiCl4 in TMC catalysts activated by TIBA would yield the initial active species C*-2-A and C*-2-B, respectively. These initial active species C*-2-A and C*-2-B with low stereoregularity transferred gradually to species C*-1-A and C*-1-B with higher stereoregularity by the absorption of AlR2Cl on the Mg adjacent to the Ti species, respectively [41,42]. The different species like C*-A and C*-B might result polyisoprenes with different microstructure. The ratio of C*-2-A to C*-2-B in TMC catalysts with increased titanium content might decrease, which could explain the different microstructure of polyisoprenes with different TMC catalysts. 3.2.3 M w and M w/M n of polyisoprene The M w and M w/M n of the polymers obtained at different polymerization time by using TMC catalysts with different titanium content were shown in Table 2 and Fig. 7 . The polymers produced by TMC-1 at the initial polymerization stage (5 min) had relatively low M w and narrow MWD as shown in Fig. 7a. As the polymerization time increased, two-peak GPC curves with a tendency of decreasing low-molecular weight fractions and increasing high-molecular weight fractions were observed for polymers with TMC-1 catalyst with an increase in polymerization time. The polymers from TMC-2 and TMC-3 catalysts showed prevailing high M w fractions in the initial polymerization time (5 min) and the GPC curves shifted toward the high M w direction with the increase in the polymerization time. These results reflected that the initial active species C*-2-A in TMC-1 presented low M w feature, while the initial active species C*-2-B in TMC-2 and TMC-3 showed relatively high M w feature. Although the transformation from low M w C*-2 to high M w C*-1 were observed, TMC-1 showed much slower transformation. Therefore, these results further confirmed the initial titanium structures in TMC-1, TMC-2 and TMC-3 were different. In order to investigate the active center distribution of TMC catalyst with different titanium content, the GPC curves were treated by the fitting split and 3–4 Flory components were obtained [42,85–87], which were marked as site 1, site 2, site 3, and site 4 (see supplementary data Fig. S2 and Table S1), each of these sites representing one kind of active centers [37]. The Flory components of polymers obtained with TMC catalysts at different polymerization time are shown in Fig. 8 . Site 1 and site 2 representing species with low molecular weight feature produced components with M w less than 14.0 × 104, and site 3 and site 4 representing species with high molecular weight feature produced components with M w more than 30.0 × 104. When the polymerization time was 5 min, the content of the low M w component from TMC-1 catalyst reached 73.2 %, and the content of the low M w fraction from TMC-2 catalyst was 22.2 % (Fig. 8b and Table S1). When the polymerization time was 30 min, the content of the low M w component from TMC-1 catalyst reduced to 32 %, and the content of the low M w fraction from TMC-2 catalyst was reduced to 16 % (Fig. 8d and Table S1). An obvious increase in the high M w fractions and its M w were observed for all TMC catalysts with the increase in the polymerization time, as Fig. 8 indicated. According to the above experimental results, it also can be confirmed that the low titanium content TMC-1 catalyst with more isolated mononuclear titanium species yielded initial active centers (C*-2-A) with low steric hindrance which produced polymers (from site 1 and site2) with low trans-1,4 units and low M w. The medium high titanium content TMC-2 catalyst with more clustered mononuclear titanium species yielded initial active centers (C*-2-B) with high steric hindrance which synthesized polymers with high trans-1,4- units and high M w. The high titanium content TMC-3 catalyst with larger-size clustered mononuclear titanium species yielded initial active centers (C*-2-C) with higher steric hindrance which synthesized polymers with higher trans-1,4- units and higher M w. 3.3 Discussions on the structure and catalytic features of the Ti species There are at least four kinds of TiCl4 species on the surface of MgCl2 including isolated monomeric TiCl4 species, clustered monomeric titanium species with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface in TMC-2, larger-size clustered monomeric titanium species with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface in TMC-3 and physisorbed mononuclear TiCl4 with tetrahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface in the TMC catalysts. (Scheme 1 ). 1) The isolated mononuclear TiCl4 with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface (A precursors) as the major precursors in TMC-1 catalyst could rapidly react with the TIBA to form C*-2-A (Ti3+) species with much lower steric hindrance, which show features like higher catalytic activity and yield polymers with much lower stereoregularity and lower molecular weight (Scheme 2 A). 2) The clustered mononuclear TiCl4 with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface (B precursors) as the major precursors in TMC-2 catalyst react with the TIBA to form C*-2-B (Ti3+) species with medium high steric hindrance, which show features like medium high catalytic activity, yield polymers with medium high stereoregularity and medium high molecular weight [42]. However, only a small portion of the titanium species in the clustered TiCl4 have the possibility to be activated to form C*-2-B, which might result in relatively low CA in the intial polymerization stage when compared to that of TMC-1 (Scheme 2B). As the polymerization proceeds, more buried or hidden titanium species are reacted with TIBA to form new active centers. Therefore, the [C*]/[Ti] increases with the increase in polymerization time for catalyst with medium high titanium content. The clustered structures not only increase the steric hindrance of the Ti species, which result the increased isotacticity and M w of the polymers obtained, but also affect the CA, which is reflected by the reduced kp. The low steric hindered active centers C*-2-A and C*-2-B allow isoprene to coordinate in the s-cis conformation to form an anti-form π-allyl chain end, resulting in polyisoprene with cis-1,4 structure and low M w. However, this anti-form π-allyl groups are thermodynamically unstable ones and will gradually transform into syn-form groups and result the trans-1,4 units. 3) The larger-size clustered mononuclear TiCl4 with octahedral ligands for Ti atoms on MgCl2 (110) crystal surface in TMC-3 catalyst react with the TIBA to form C*-2-C (Ti3+) species with high steric hindrance, which show features like high CA, yield polymers with high stereoregularity and high M w. 4) The mononuclear TiCl4 on MgCl2 (110) with the Ti atom in a tetrahedral coordination in TMC catalyst could easily depart from the catalyst surface as the free TiCl4 with trace activity [57]. As the polymerization proceeded, some C*-2 species might be temporarily deactivated by reversible complexation of the Al(i-Bu)2Cl on the active species (C*-3-A and C*-3-B), or transform into C*-1 active centers by adsorption and complexation of Al(i-Bu)2Cl on the Mg atom adjacent to the active species (C*-1-A and C*-1-B) [41,42]. The isoprene monomers prefer to coordinate on the highly sterically hindered C*-1 active centers in the s-trans conformation to form syn-form π-allyl chain ends, and finally yield polymers with high trans-1,4 structure and high M w [41]. As the titanium content in the TMC catalyst increased, both the size of clustered mononuclear titanium species and the number of mononuclear TiCl4 in a tetrahedral coordination increase, and resulte much lower CA, much lower number of active specie, much lower kp, but produce polymers with relatively higher trans-1,4 units and M w. 4 Conclusion In the early stages of isoprene polymerization with the TMC, the monomeric titanium precatalysts including isolated species and clustered species are activated to intial active centers C*-2 with lower steric hindrance, which show higher CA and produce polymers with lower trans-1,4 units and lower M w. As the polymerization time increases, this low stereoregular active center C*-2 could be converted into a highly stereoregular active center C*-1 by the adsorption of AlR2Cl on the Mg atom adjacent to the active center (Ti), and eventually C*-1 as the dominated active centers show lower CA but yield polymers with higher trans-1,4 units and higher M w. Low titanium content catalysts (TMC-1) containing a large amount of isolated mononuclear titanium precatalysts are activated to form C*-2-A species which show high CA and yield polymers with lower trans-1,4 units and lower M w at the beginning of the polymerization. The medium high titanium content catalysts (TMC-2) with increased clustered mononuclear titanium precatalysts are activated to form C*-2-B species which show relatively low CA and yield polymers with relatively high trans-1,4 units and high M w in the initial polymerization. As the titanium content in the TiCl4/MgCl2 catalyst increased, both the size of clustered mononuclear titanium species and the number of mononuclear TiCl4 with tetrahedral coordination increase, and result much lower CA, much lower number of active species, much lower kp, but produce polymers with relatively higher trans-1,4 units and M w. coredata.dc:description: The isoprene polymerization kinetics by using TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts (TMC) with different titanium contents were studied for better understanding the possible active-specie structures of heterogeneous Ziegler-Natta (Z-N) catalysts for conjugated diene polymerizations. The catalytic features including the catalytic activity (CA), number of active centers ([C*]/[Ti]), rate constant for polymerization (kp), stereoregularity of these TMC catalysts were studied. The low titanium content catalyst TMC-1 (Ti = 0.09 wt.%) with more isolated mononuclear titanium species showed higher CA and yielded cis-1,4-/trans-1,4- mixed microstructure polyisoprene with low molecular weight (M w) in the initial polymerization stage. The medium high titanium content catalyst TMC-2 (Ti = 2.38 wt.%) with more clustered mononuclear titanium species showed lower CA and yielded cis-1,4-/trans-1,4- mixed microstructure polyisoprene with high M w in the early stage of polymerization. The high titanium content catalyst TMC-3 (Ti = 3.76 wt.%) presented lowest CA and yielded high trans-1,4- polyisoprene with higher M w.
coredata.dc:title: Isoprene polymerizations catalyzed by TiCl4/MgCl2 type Ziegler-Natta catalysts with different titanium contents
